title: Queen's Speech: Your pension savings are about to change
text:

Pensions used to be simple, put a portion of your wages away while you were working in return for a portion of your salary paid to you when you retire.

But that hasn't been the case for a while.

Now, workers and firms save into pots you can access later in life and do with as you please – with salary based pensions almost exclusively the preserve of public servants or legacy schemes.

This presents a problem, as people move between jobs it's easy to lose track of what you have saved, where, and what it's worth.

Which is why it's great news there are finally plans in place to force firms to make it easier for you to find out.

(Image: REUTERS)

The “Pensions dashboard” is a single place to visit giving you information on exactly what you've got saved, where, and what it is likely to be worth once you retire.

Tom Selby, senior analyst at AJ Bell, said: “Dashboards have the potential to revolutionise retirement engagement in the UK by allowing savers to see all their pensions in one place."

But it won't work if some firms simply opt out.

Tom McPhail, Hargreaves Lansdown Head of policy, added: "The key to making it work is to force all pension providers to open up their data, which this legislation will now do."

And once in place - they could make managing your money a lot easier.

“In the long-term there is no reason Dashboards can’t be expanded to including other financial products such as ISAs, as well as providing information on things like costs and charges to help people shop around for the best deal," Selby said.

“The likes of Monzo have shown the way in the banking world, and I expect pensions to follow a similar path in the coming years.”

But that was just one of the new rules set out in the Queen's speech.

There were also new laws planned around both how you save and access your money.

First was saving – with plans announced for new “collective” workplace pensions schemes.

These would see staff and firms pay into a single, shared, pot rather than individual pots for each person.

The idea is that it could be more efficient and offer better value - as well as a bit more certainty about what you get back at the end.

So far, Royal Mail are the main people trying this "collective defined contribution" idea out.

“The Collective Defined Contribution provisions will enable to the Royal Mail to press ahead with their plans to develop this new half-way house type of scheme, which gives its members some certainty over their future benefits, without the full guarantees you get from a final salary scheme," McPhail said.

"Whether any other employers follow the Royal Mail lead in the future is uncertain; there’s currently no sign of a queue forming."

(Image: iStockphoto)

Finally there were new rules planned about where, when and who you can transfer your pension to.

These are needed as there have been cases where scammers have convinced people to move their money and honest firms have been powerless to stop it.

According to the Pensions Regulator, 100,000 people transferred their money out of an old-style pension in the past year alone.

While most of these will be switched to a new style "pot" rather than a set annual payout, there is a risk they are being sent to scammers - who frequently operate overseas where regulation is weaker and promise people access their cash early.

In response the Queen's speech promised "regulations to set out circumstances under which a pension scheme member will have the right to transfer their pension savings to another scheme".

Selby said: “Previously there has been a real tension between the right of savers to move their money to a different scheme, which is clearly very important, and the responsibilities on providers in blocking transfers to suspect schemes.

"Addressing this tension will help ensure fewer people fall victim to pensions fraud.”
description: Once you put money into a pension, it's tied up until you're at least 55 – mostly - but new rules look set to shut the loopholes that some people are exploiting
